_prev_prog_3.Description:
The following is brief summary of the prevention program in place at Moorhead Water Treatment Plant to reduce the risk of a chlorine release. 



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



Moorhead Public Service recognizes that it is essential to involve its employees in the development and implementation of an OSHA PSM and EPA RMP Program at all Moorhead Public Service facilities subject to the OSHA PSM and/or EPA RMP regulations. The purpose of this plan is to define how employees will be involved.



Employees have been significantly involved in the development of the prevention program, especially in the areas of process hazard analysis, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures. They have been trained on and encouraged to review all areas of the prevention program.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



Complete and up-to-date process safety information is required to successfully implement most RMP Program elements, including PHAs, training, emergency planning and response, management of change, incident investigation, and compliance audits. The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that current written process safety information is developed and maintained in a format that provides easy access by employees, PHA teams, and auditors.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



In 2017, Moorhead Public Service conducted a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation using Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) method to identify, evaluate, and control the risk associated with process hazards or changes implemented to the chlorine system highly hazardous chemical (HHC) release scenarios at all Moorhead Public Service facilities subject to the OSHA PSM and/or EPA RMP regulations. The overall purpose of the PHA changes was to ensure compliance with these EPA regulations and to prevent or minimize the effects of a chemical release. Recommendations were made during the PHA to reduce the risk associated with a hazard or release scenario to an acceptable level. 



OPERATING PROCEDURES



The purpose of the process change in 2012 was to improve safety at the Moorhead Water Plant by removing pressurized piping from the chlorine system and replace it with vacuum components. Feeding chlorine gas by vacuum significantly reduces the risk of a chlorine leak.  Procedures were created/updated for the new equipment based on manufacturer recommendations. All documents relating to Standard Operating Procedures are reviewed by staff on an annual basis to ensure best practices are being followed. Revalidation of these processes took place during the 2017 PHA and 2018 RMP audits.  



PERSONNEL TRAINING



The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that personnel working on or near OSHA PSM and/or EPA RMP-regulated processes are adequately trained and understand the inherent process hazards and appropriate response actions to accidental chemical releases. Regulated processes at the facility include the chlorination processes.



CONTRACTOR SAFETY



The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that only contractors with good health and safety programs are selected to perform work on and around processes that use highly hazardous chemicals, and that the contractors and the processes are properly prepared to safely complete the work. Processes that use highly hazardous chemicals currently include the chlorine processes.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW



A Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) will be performed for new processes regulated under OSHA PSM and EPA RMP, and modified existing regulated processes when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that the facility is ready to safely operate new and modified regulated processes.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



The purpose of the mechanical integrity program is to ensure the continued integrity of process equipment. An effective mechanical integrity program is integral to preventing accidental chemical releases that may result from mechanical failure of improperly maintained equipment. The program follows manufacturer's recommendations for maintenance of equipment. Some maintenance schedules for equipment have been modified from the manufactures recommendations based on experience with the equipment. 



HOT WORK PERMITS



The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that a hot work permit is issued for all hot work operations conducted on or near the chlorine processes. Hot work is defined as any work that may generate a source of ignition and includes but is not limited to welding, torch cutting, and use of spark-producing equipment.





MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



The purpose of the Management of Change (MoC) procedure is to ensure that system changes are properly reviewed against original system design specifications and can be accomplished safely, and that the systems are ready to operate safely in accordance with original system design intent following implementation of the change.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



All incidents at the Moorhead Water Plant, which resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in a release of chlorine, will be promptly investigated. The purpose of the incident investigation procedure is to identify the underlying cause(s) of an incident and to implement corrective actions to prevent the incident from reoccurring.





COMPLIANCE AUDITS



The purpose of compliance audits is to ensure audits are performed to evaluate Moorhead Water Plant process safety and risk management programs, and their implementation for compliance with the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP regulations. Whenever necessary, the audit will identify recommendations to address program deficiencies.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This executive summary is a brief overview of the RMP and the associated policies at the Moorhead Water Treatment Plant, owned and operated by Moorhead Public Service.  It contains all of the information required by Section 68.155 2017.



RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The accidental release prevention policies are represented in Sections 2 through 13 of this document. The emergency response policy is represented in Sections 14.  MPS takes an active role in preventing accidental releases at this facility by ensuring that its employees are properly trained in the safe operation and maintenance of processes subject to the Part 68 rule.  They are also trained in the safe handling of all chemicals regulated by the rule.



In addition to ensure its employees are adequately trained, MPS works to prevent accidents by providing and revising written procedures for operating its covered processes, as needed, under the rule. Although these procedures in and of themselves should prevent accidental releases, MPS maintains and follows a policy of compliance audits, the goals of which are to determine if existing procedures are adequate and, if they are, to ensure that they are followed.



MPS has also developed and maintained a risk management policy that contains general safety rules.  The general safety rules fall under Minnesota's Chapter 182 Occupational Safety and Health Act.  The safety and health program is required to meet Minnesota's A Workplace Accident and Incident Reduction (AWAIR) Program. This program covers topics such as personal protection equipment, hazard communications, confined space, respiratory protection, excavation and trenching, lock-out/tag-out, and bloodborne disease exposure control.  Although these general rules do not specifically address the covered processes and their regulated substances, compliance with the general rules will significantly reduce the potential for accidental release of these substan

ces.  The manuals for this program are available to all MPS employees in the control room of the Moorhead Water Treatment Plant. 



As for emergency response, Moorhead Public Service's procedure for a release is to notify the Moorhead Fire Department. The City of Moorhead Fire Department and the City of Fargo, North Dakota Fire Department jointly operate and maintain a HAZMAT team. Moorhead Public Service has established and maintained procedures for emergency evacuation of employees and accounting for them. These procedures will enable the HAZMAT team to perform their duties more efficiently. The procedures are reviewed with employees on an annual basis and revised to accommodate changes in staffing when they occur.



Moorhead Public Service's procedure for a release is to notify the Moorhead Fire Department. The Moorhead Fire Department operates and maintains a HAZMAT Team. MPS has established and maintained procedures for emergency evacuation and roll call of employees. These procedures enable the Moorhead HAZMAT Team to perform their duties more efficiently. The procedures are reviewed with employees on an annual basis and revised to accomodate changes in staffing when they occur.



Moorhead Public Service modeled two release scenarios in 2012, and updated in early 2018: a worst case release scenario and an alternate case release scenario. In the worst case release scenario, EPA defined parameters were used with the local three-year maximum temperature and average relative humidity. The radius of the modeled chlorine plume was updated to 2.1 miles and had a potential population impact of 31,774 65,176 in Moorhead and surrounding communities. In the alternate release scenario, a leaky ton cylinder on a delivery truck was modeled. This release reached approximately 155 yards.  The residential population impacted was zero, but employees at the site would be affected.   



Moorhead Public Service management understands its duty to provide a safe working environm

ent at this facility and to take measures to prevent accidents that may have an effect on the surrounding communities. This understanding is reflected in procedures described and referenced in this document.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Moorhead WTP treats surface water from the Red River of the North and ground water from the Moorhead and Buffalo Aquifers to provide drinking water to the cities of Moorhead and Dilworth. Water is treated through a series of physical and chemical treatment operations including lime softening, ozone disinfection and recarbonation, filtration, and secondary disinfection using monochloramines. The MWTP design capacity is 16 million gallons per day.



The regulated substance stored, handled, and used at this facility is chlorine, which is stored onsite in one-ton containers and is used to disinfect treated water. The maximum intended inventory of chlorine is four (4) one-ton cylinders, or 8,000 pounds of chlorine on site.  All of the containers are stored inside of a temperature controlled building.



RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM FOR COVERED CHEMICALS



The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in Section 2 through Section 13 of this document.  In accordance with the Part 68 rule, the prevention program contains the following sections:



  >Employee Participation (Section 2)

  >Process Safety Information (Section 3)

  >Process Hazard Analysis (Section 4)

  >Standard Operating Procedures (Section 5) 

  >Personnel Training (Section 6)

  >Contractor Safety (Section 7)

  >Pre-Startup Safety Review (Section 8)

  >Mechanical Integrity (Section 9)

  >Hot Work Permits (Section 10)

  >Management of Change (Section 11)

  >Incident Investigation (Section 12)

  >Compliance Audits (Section 13)



The prevention program elements that are most critical in preventing accidental releases in this facility include employee training, both formal and on-the-job; written operatin

g procedures for all to use who operate or maintain the covered processes; and a process equipment preventive maintenance program.



Should the prevention program fail to prevent a release, the MWTP is equipped with engineering controls designed to minimize the effect of the release to the surrounding communities.  The chlorine containers are kept inside of a building to mitigate the effects of the release.  More importantly, MWTP has installed a scrubber capable of neutralizing one ton of chlorine, the amount stored in the largest single container on-site.  The scrubber is maintained twice monthly to ensure proper operation in case it would be needed during a chlorine release. In addition, an automatic Halogen Valve shutdown system for the online ton cylinder tank valves is installed. If a leak is detected by online monitors, the shutdown system is activated and will close the cylinder valves, reducing the impact of a leak. The MWTP also has a 1.3 MW natural gas generator for back-up power for the chlorine scrubber that was installed in 2015 as part of the High Service Pumping Station Project.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidental releases of regulated substances from this facility during the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This facility has established and maintains an emergency evacuation procedure for employees. The emergency response to a chlorine release is coordinated by local response agencies, such as the Moorhead Fire Department. which is part of the local HAZMAT team along with the City of Fargo, North Dakota. There are no employees at Moorhead Public Service either trained or designated as emergency responders for the chlorine system. The Emergency Planning and Response documentation kept by the facility is described in detail in Section 14 of this document.  The goals of the program are to protect onsite employees from the hazardous effects of a release. The overall prevention program and onsite safety equipme

nt are designed to minimize the effects of releases on the general public. The program is routinely reviewed and updated to reflect personnel and regulatory changes.  A copy of the facility OSHA PSM and EPA RMP program is located at the Moorhead Fire Department for review.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVED SAFETY



Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought from employees. Employee safety meetings that focus on chlorine safety issues are held regularly at this facility. Employees are encouraged and trained to recognize hazards and present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of those hazards.

 

In 2012, pressurized piping and V-notch chlorinators were replaced with flexible and rigid PVC tubing, Hydro-Omni Valves and vacuum regulators. The new system components feed chlorine gas via vacuum directly from the tank valve to the Hydro-Omni Valve where it is mixed into utility water solution and fed into the water supply for disinfection. Removing pressurized piping along with other safeguards such as chlorine gas detectors, automatic shutoff valves, and a chlorine scrubber reduce the risks associated with chlorine gas. Staff is continuously evaluating options for improving chlorine safety. 



During the development of this RMP document, hazard reviews were conducted with key employees to meet the prevention program requirements. During these sessions, recommendations were made for the purpose of improving safety and preventing accidental chemical releases. Each recommendation was considered and evaluated for implementation.
